Award.AwardTitle: RET Site on "Challenge-Based Learning and Engineering Design Process Enhanced Research Experiences for Middle and High School In-Service Teachers"

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides funding for a three year standard award to support a Research Experiences for Teachers (RET) in Engineering and Computer Science Site program at the University of Cincinnati (UC) entitled, RET Site on "Challenge-Based Learning and Engineering Design Process (EDP) Enhanced Research Experiences for Middle and High School In-Service Teachers", under the direction of Dr. Anant Kukreti, Director for Engineering Outreach, College of Engineering and Applied Science.

This proposal establishes a RET Site for a total of 36 (12 per year) STEM in-service middle and high school teachers in Challenge-Based Learning (CBL) and Engineering Design Process (EDP) pedagogy. The goals are three fold: 1) To educate, cultivate, and enrich science and math teachers' content delivery in their classrooms by exploring the engineering design-and challenge for 7-weeks during the summer. 2) To improve grades 7-12 students' science and math achievement and stimulate interest in STEM careers as a result of better instruction and curriculum delivered by participating teachers trained in engineering content and design-based instruction. 3) To support participating teachers in becoming role models by applying their research experiences in their classrooms and communicating them effectively to their colleagues. The RET Site builds on the proven success of 2 NSF RET Sites, 5 NSF REU Sites, and 2 RET Supplements.

This RET Site broadens the impact of the current Cincinnati Engineering Enhanced Mathematics and Science Program (CEEMS), a NSF Targeted Math & Science Partnership (MSP) Program grant, which includes 14 Ohio school districts with 73,392 students and 4,709 teachers. This RET Site includes 14 non-CEEMS school districts (12 in Ohio and 2 in Kentucky) with 72,546 students and 4,369 teachers. Since RET and CEEMS teachers both develop and test curriculum design, teaching techniques, and student learning modalities using CBL-EDP pedagogy and include 71.1% of the students regionally in Ohio, collectively they will clearly impact the way math and science curricula are delivered to meet new standards regionally.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We obtained a RET Site grant with a one-year no-cost extension, implemented from 2014 to 2017; for total of 4 years. The RET implemented projects met the growing need for engineering educated middle and high school teachers who are equipped to provide learners with opportunities to achieve recently revised Ohio State Science Standards and Common Core Mathematics Standards juxtaposed with Universal Skills (21st Century Learning Skills). Preparation of such teachers allowed them to: 

  1. Educate, cultivate, and enrich science and math teachers’ content delivery in their classrooms by exploring the engineering design-and-challenge instruction process and the critical research skills used by engineers to solve open-ended real-world problems.
  2. Improve 7-12 grade students’ science and math achievement and stimulate interest in STEM careers as a result of better instruction and curriculum delivered by participating teachers trained in engineering content and design-based instruction.
  3. Become role models by applying their research experiences in their classrooms and communicating them effectively to their colleagues.

Thirty-three (14 men and 19 women; 31 white Caucasians and 2 ethnic minorities; and 24 masters and 9 bachelor degree holders) elementary, middle and high school math and science teachers were trained, bringing their experiences and knowledge into 28 schools (2 elementary, 6 middle and 20 high schools) in the greater Cincinnati and Northern Kentucky area, which included 16 school districts and 5 private schools. These teachers developed 21 science, 10 mathematics, and 2 integrated STEM curricular Units. Over 1,650 students have been impacted through these Units. Teachers disseminated their experience through 24 conference presentations.

During the RET Sites teachers participated in an upfront 1-week workshop series in understanding engineering education, design practices, and career opportunities through an Engineering Foundations course. Thereafter, teachers participated in a 6-week summer engineering research immersion (half-day) under the guidance of engineering faculty members and graduate students. The RET research projects selected each year addressed engineering and cybersecurity grand challenges. Additionally, teachers participated in a structured professional development educational program (half-day) including: 1) challenge-based learning (CBL) and engineering design process (EDP) classroom teaching pedagogies and assessment enrichment seminars; 2) research and curricular material dissemination skill-building workshops; 3) experiential learning field trips; and 4) year-long coaching support as they executed classroom implementations. The CBL approach fostered student teamwork in which each team identified a challenge of interest to them and then worked through the use of the EDP to seek out one or more solutions, and then defended the best solution.

The teachers produced five primary deliverables during the summer RET Site: 1) a Team Project Report, including the research report and individual teacher classroom implementation plans; 2) a Team PowerPoint showcasing both research completed and classroom implementation plan; 3) an Individual Teacher Poster illustrating the research highlights and the teacher’s lesson to students; 4) a Team Video (3-minute) showcasing the teachers’ summer work for a K-12 audience; and 5) a draft Teacher Journal Paper or PowerPoint. After teaching during the school year following the summer RET program, teachers presented a new set of RET deliverables pertaining to the Unit they had taught which included a poster, PowerPoint and video. The final post implementation Unit template submitted by each teacher included a reflection, student pre- and post-test and assessment results, and differentiations addressed during teaching. Both the summer and post-teaching deliverables were presented by the teachers to a panel of engineers and educators.

In summary, the RET teachers learned practical research applications, technical writing, curricular Unit planning, and presentation skills and appreciated the time spent with both graduate research assistant and faculty mentor. They demonstrated an increased understanding of “engineering design process and research” skills and their own confidence in using them. Many of the teachers have become “Teacher Leaders” who have successively demonstrated the skills to transfer the experience and knowledge gained to train other teachers. Through RET teachers’ instruction, the percentage of students’ who agreed or strongly agreed that they were more interested in engineering ranged from 46-66% across the four years from 2014-2017; 85-95% of them said they learned from the RET teachers’ lessons, and 54-66% increased their confidence in learning science and mathematics. Students “felt that using challenges is a more effective way to learn than the way they are usually taught” (means of 3.0, 3.0, 3.3, and 3.4 out of 4 for 2014-2017, respectively). Positive teacher ratings from students included teachers providing “guidance when asked for” (means of 3.4, 3.4, 3.5 and 3.6 out of 5, for 2014-2017, respectively). The additional open-ended student responses support these numbers. In summary, students reported that activities were fun and they learned about research and the research process. Student feedback supports that the RET teacher Units were an effective way to learn science and math and building confidence in these disciplines.
